channel.title: Anatomy vs Physiology
channel.description:
I have a test tomorrow in Anatomy, so I've been studying over various different things. So far, the only thing that has caught my attention is function vs structure. Below is a list I have compiled together to label each phrase as either physiology or anatomy.
[b]Anatomy:[/b]
[ul][li]can be studied in dead specimen[/li] [li]principles of physics[/li] [li]observing a heart in action[/li] [li]dissection[/li] [li]directional terms[/li] [li]static[/li][/ul]
[b]Physiology:[/b]
[ul][li]dynamic[/li] [li]experimentation[/li] [li]observation[/li] [li]often studied in living subjects[/li] [li]chemistry principles[/li] [li]measuring the acid content of the stomach[/li][/ul]
If you have experience with Anatomy, please tell me if you think these terms fit in the right category.

item.title: Anatomy vs Physiology
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

yea it depends what you are observing it for

Read full topic

item.title: Anatomy vs Physiology
item.dc:creator: @Tutorial Tutorial
item.description:
@Tutorial wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:2, topic:528908”]observing a heart in action

isnt that physiology?

When I took A&P they said anatomy was just about the layout of the body and where things were, whereas physiology was about how all of those things function[/quote]
This is what we were taught, and I found a list on medial site to support the above categories. I do agree that the only thing that makes observing a heart physiology is the ‘action’ part. I’ll have to double check with my teacher tomorrow, because there are quite a few things that we have learned so far that seem contradictory. It’s amazing how one word can offset the entire phrase.

Thanks for the response.

Read full topic
